original_title: Sri Lanka economist Amal Sanderatne remembered with admiration
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka economist Amal Sanderatne, founder of Frontier Research, an independent research consultancy, passed away under tragic circumstances and is remembered with admiration by industry colleagues and  friends for his unbiased research and personal integrity.

Sanderatne studied at London School of Economics and was Economist and later was Head of Research at Jardine Fleming HNB Securities. In his student days he also did stint at the Sunday Times Business section as a financial reporter.
He was invited to move to Singapore after Jardine Fleming was taken over by JP Morgan Chase and the US group exited Sri Lanka in around 2001.

Sanderatne came back and set up Frontier Research. He was widely respected and admired for generating research and forecasts on macro-economic developments and capital markets, based on deep analysis and probabilities.
Sri Lanka top companies started to consult him for economic projections.
“He brought research to the boardroom,” says Ajith Fernando, who heads Sri Lanka’s Capital Alliance group.
“He had no agenda. He was weighing pros and cons and presented forecasts with a balanced stand and probabilities.
Sanderatne changed the way boards and companies took decisions based on economic projections, Fernando says.
When Capital Alliance went into stockbroking, Fernando outsourced research to Sanderatne’s company.
Sanderatne was selected as one of the 100 thought leaders of Sri Lanka by Echelon Magazine.
Deva Ellepola, then General Manager of HNB Securities says Amal was a quiet person with brilliant analysis. He had set up his consultancy when such research was uncommon and was a “rare breed”.
“I would say he filled a huge vacuum in the market place,” Ellepolla said. “He was insightful. He always helpful.:
When JP Morgan pulled out of Sri Lanka HNB Securities Ellepolla had to set up the research department from scratch Amal had helped find an expert from Singapore to do the work.

“What I most admired was his integrity, both professionally and personally,” says Sharhan Mushin, who was at one time Economist and Head of Banking Research and Jardine Fleming HNB had moved to Singapore at the same time.
“He had the highest level of integrity. He was balanced and reasonable.
“Amal was someone who saw people through their potential and capacities for great work rather than through qualifications,” said Thilina Panduwawala, Head of Research at Frontier Research.
“While the public knows him as an economist, we knew him most closely as the best boss we could work with. His legacy will be carried on in our own work.”

“Amal was the best boss one could hope for, and has been the guiding light for all of us at Frontier now and in the past, adds Chayu Damsinghe, who heads Macroecomomic and Thematic Research at Frontier.
“Although he is no longer with us, he will live on in all the lives he’s touched with his kindness.”
